Go Big or Go Homer is the second episode of Season 31, originally produced for Season 30.

Synopsis[]

Homer is demoted to supervising interns, among whom is go-getter millennial Mike, a 35-year-old who asks Homer to be his mentor. However, when Homer inspires Mike to start a business of his own, the two find themselves being chased by the mob.

Plot[]

The nuclear plant workers are giving Lenny a surprise birthday party. Everyone signs a greeting card and gives $5 to the envelope. Just before Lenny, Mr. Burns comes to the party. Although he leaves no money for the jubilee, his signature covers the entire surface of the birthday card and spoils the surprise by wishing the employee wishes to everyone. Homer Simpson is furious all through the party.

Marge Simpson comforts him and helps him calm down. Then her breast pierces the swirl from Mr. Burns' signature. Homer wakes up screaming, but it turns out that it was only a dream and he cannot reconcile with the boss' behavior.

The next day, he goes to demand $5 from Mr. Burns. The billionaire gives him the required amount without thinking. When Homer leaves his office, Smithers accuses him of using Mr. Burns in a moment of weakness, because under the influence of drugs for thickening the skin, he becomes very gentle. As a punishment, Homer is relegated to a lower position, which he is to now on, supervise the work of interns. The new occupation is not the easiest one because young people laugh at the lecturer's ineptitude. Suddenly, a red-haired boy named Mike Wegman pleads for him, begging Homer to become his mentor. This word alone makes it feel appreciated. That's why he goes to Costington's with his family to buy a new tie. In the store, however, is ridiculed by everyone when the escalator grabs his pants.

As Homer shows Mike around Sector 7G, he finds out that the boy is actually 35 years old. He is surprised why an adult dreams of working for a student. Mike tells him that he would like to start the way he did. He is convinced that his mentor enjoys the respect of all friends. Homer decides to invite him over for dinner to show his family the treatment he deserves.

Marge is not happy about Mike's visit because Homer tells her at the last minute. The boy comes to the Simpsons’s house with his wife, Maureen Wegman, who is expecting her and Mike’s child. At the table, Bart Simpson disregards the guest and his attachment to Homer; In response, Mike throws the boy some insults. Upset, he runs away to his room, crying. Marge decides to throws Mike out the house, and advises Homer to help his pupil grow up.

Homer tries to encourage Mike to start making his own dreams come true. He learns that the boy wants to start a business and sell pizza pieces. Hoping that Mr. Burns is under the influence of drugs, Homer asks him to become a sponsor. When he refuses, Mike explodes again and insults the boss. In response, Mr. Burns aims at him from the merger.

Since Mike can't accept the idea that Homer is a bad mentor, he decides to prove to him at all costs that his advice was helpful to him. That's why he opens a pizza booth and drives up a new van to the Simpsons' house. However, it quickly becomes apparent that he bought it with money borrowed from Fit-Fat Tony, who demands settlement.

Escaping from the Springfield Mafia after losing a bet to them, Homer and Mike hide in a car dump, right next to the food truck cemetery. Fit-Fat Tony and his associates surround the two upon finding them and prepare for execution. Suddenly, the mafia smells of mozzarella from Mike's van. Homer quickly distributes pizza pieces to them. Liking the pizza pieces’ taste, Fit-Fat Tony and the mafia decide that Mike will pay off the loan by running bookmakers simultaneously with the food track. The van stands in front of the power plant and in addition to the services mentioned above, it also sells marijuana. Fit-Fat Tony then states that Homer is a great mentor, much to the latter’s happiness.
